Award.AwardTitle: Resolving rapid radiations and recent speciation in North American spiny lizards (Sceloporus)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding rapid bursts of speciation requires new phylogenetic methods as well as large data sets. In this project, the investigators will study a group of lizards (genus Sceloporus) to resolve rapid radiations and recent speciation events in the tree of life. The accumulation of new species over brief time intervals characterizes both of these events, which are challenging to elucidate because they leave limited genetic signatures across the genome. The investigators will apply new DNA sequencing technologies to investigate rapid speciation; determine the feasibility of analyzing extremely large genomic datasets using new models; and stress-test inference methods to identify the analytical upper limits of dataset size and complexity.

Promoting the progress of science and the integration of research and education will involve four activities: 1) education and public outreach at The Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, including a new public exhibit on the integration of genomics and natural history research, 2) postdoctoral mentoring, 3) undergraduate and graduate student training, and 4) the acquisition and dissemination of new comparative genomics data. Lizards in the North American genus Sceloporus are prominent in comparative studies of ecology, physiology, life history evolution, and chromosome evolution. This organismal research will yield a robust new estimate of the evolutionary history of these lizards, a valuable commodity for the comparative biology community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award facilitated new discoveries related to the application of genome sequencing technologies to the study of evolution and diversification. A comparison of new genomic data acquisition procedures was conducted to determine the feasibility of analyzing large genomic datasets using existing methods. This procedure was successful at identifying critical shortcomings in existing models. New methods were developed and implemented in computer software to provide the scientific community with improved methods for analyzing genomic data. These new products included an online genomics data processing tool, a method for species delimitation that can handle genome-scale data, and new models for building phylogenetic trees that account for biases in data acquisition.

The award from NSF also allowed the collection of new genetic data for 150+ species of lizards using alternative genomic data acquisition strategies. The study system was selected because it showed evidence of rapid evolution and recent speciation, two processes that are challenging to study because they leave limited genetic signatures across the genome. These data were used to produce high-resolution phylogenetic trees, which were compared to provide new perspectives on the utility of different types of genomic data for phylogenetic inference. The research discovered that some types of data are more sensitive to rapid evolution than others, and that small differences in analysis assumptions can have a dramatic impact on the resulting phylogenetic trees. These findings provided important new guidelines for future studies that plan to use genome data for phylogeny inference.

The research supported the training and participation in research of seven graduate students and three postdoctoral researchers. Together, the team produced 11 peer-reviewed publications, 15 presentations at conferences, and three new tools for genetic data processing and analysis. The research also provided genomics and computational biology training to visiting scientists from other U.S. institutions and abroad (Greece, Mexico, Argentina, and Chile). New genome data obtained for 150+ lizard species were deposited online in public databases to facilitate future research. Research findings were disseminated to the general public in displays at the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture.
